title: Introduction
instruction: Click the play button to start the video.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Since the 1970s, healthcare for patients in the correctional system has been the subject of widespread intervention by federal courts. As creators and supporters of electronic healthcare record software, it is necessary to understand the unique challenges and opportunities presented by working in the correctional healthcare space. Virtually everyone in a country like America has some experience with the healthcare system.

 The corrections system also provides their patients with many of the same healthcare services, with several key differences; the way a corrections patient accesses healthcare or meets with a specialty clinician is almost unrecognizable compared to the way someone with health insurance and a primary care provider might. What if a patient in corrections gets sick or injured? What if a patient with a physical injury needs adaptive equipment? How does a patient schedule a routine visit such as a yearly physical? Almost everyone outside of corrections has been through one of the situations above, but very few had a reason or need to know how someone in corrections would do the same.

 This course will introduce and illustrate some of the scenarios that take place when a patient is introduced into the correctional healthcare flow and makes use of some of the services available to patients therein.

title: Lexicon
body: These are some commonly-used terms in correctional healthcare.
instruction: Click each heading to expand it and learn more.

_items.title: Custody
_items.body: This is the receiving office of the correctional facility. Here, a patient turns in their property and documents. Their fingerprints and picture are taken, they are given a physical exam for marks, tattoos, and contraband, and they are issued uniforms and other equipment

_items.title: JMS/OMS
_items.body: The Jail Management System or Offender Management System are a database where a patient's demographic information such as name, address, social security number, date of birth, and others are registered. The patient is also issued a record number which will be used as their unique identifier

_items.title: Nurse
_items.body: The nurse is the first healthcare provider the patient will encounter whether during initial intake or later visits

_items.title: Provider
_items.body: A mid-level practitioner such as a nurse practitioner or physician's assistant, or a doctor

_items.title: Specialist
_items.body: A healthcare provider with a speciality outside of the main workflow, such as a mental health professional, an occupational therapist, a radiologist, an oncologist, etc

_items.title: Adaptive Equipment
_items.body: Equipment for patients with substantial impairments which limit performance of major life activities. Examples of adaptive equipment include hearing aids, communication devices, wheelchairs, walkers and text magnifiers

_items.title: Sober Cell
_items.body: An area of the correctional facility providing short-term recovery, detoxification, and recuperation from the effects of acute alcohol or drug intoxiciation

_items.title: Withdrawal Medication
_items.body: Medicine that assists with the treatment of alcohol or drug addiction withdrawal symptoms; examples include lorazepam, clonazepam, methadone, or clonidine

title: Intake Workflow
body: The workflow for patient intake in correctional healthcare proceeds as follows:
instruction: (Click the map marker icons to find out more)

_items.title: Custody
_items.body:
At custody, the custody officer enters the patient into a Jail Management System(JMS) or Offender Management System(OMS).

This is a database which contains the demographic information for patients. Before the patient ever encounters correctional healthcare, they should be entered into the JMS/OMS by a corrections officer at the custody desk during their first step of entering a corrections facility. Correctional healthcare will pull the patient's information from the JMS/OMS as well as update the JMS/OMS with any necessary medical information that affects the patient's demographics.

_items.title: Nurse Intake
_items.body: In the initial intake for a patient, the patient is asked a series of questions about their medical conditions, history, and concerns, then subjected to a series of lab tests. It is important to note that a patient who is under the influence of a narcotic or alcohol will not be put through the intake process and will instead be routed to a sobering process to ensure that intake only gives accurate results for vital signs and other healthcare information. Additional screenings, such as questionnaires measuring the impact of addiction disorders, is performed during the initial medical intake, as well. When the nurse is done collecting intake information, the patient moves on to a mid-level healthcare or doctor for another intake procedure.

_items.title: Provider Intake
_items.body: The provider intake step goes more in-depth to any medical conditions, claims, or results. The provider may ask many of the same questions or go more in-depth with follow-up inquiries. During the provider intake, the provider may also prescribe withdrawal medication for addiction disorders, refer a patient to a specialist, create new or update old prescriptions, assign a 'pass' profiling the patient for certain adaptive living conditions or work conditions, or issue adaptive equipment. The provider intake and any follow-up necessary for intake mark the end of the intake process. At this point, the patient is usually assigned to a cell.

title: Sick Call
body: How patients access healthcare in corrections.
instruction: Click the play button to start the video.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody: A patient has a right to submit a grievance or sick call request at any time. A grievance may be a question or complaint unrelated to healthcare (e.g. food, a problem with a correctional officer, noise problems, phone/mail communication problems etc) and are separated by the nurse or other corrections personnel. The nurse then orders the sick call requests in order of priority, similar to triage in urgent or emergent care, then on to a specialist appointment if referred by a doctor. If medication or treatment is prescribed, the patient is returned to their usual assigned area.

title: Similarities and Differences
body:
The following is a comparison of similarities between correctional healthcare and the healthcare industry outside of corrections.
Click the arrows on the image to move through the instruction
mobileInstruction: Click the next and back arrows to find out more.

_items.title: Similarities
_items.body:
Just like in a healthcare situation in the healthcare industry outside of corrections, several levels of care are available to a patient. A patient is first seen by a nurse and, after answering preliminary questions, having vital signs measured, and having metrics examined, the patient may be escalated up to a mid-level or doctor-level practitioner

Levels of care:
If the doctor needs to consult a specialist or refer the patient to a specialty appointment, the patient may be referred by a doctor to that level of care.

Escalation of care:
Also, depending on needs, the patient may be called for a routine procedure or visit, or request urgent care, or be transported to emergency care.

_items.title: Key Differences
_items.body:
There are several key differences in correctional healthcare from civilian healthcare.

Scheduling:
Patients are not able to schedule an appointment in healthcare. A provider can, but scheduling requires a certain flexibility because patients are often moved around due to court dates, work calls, reassignment, etc. A doctor can schedule appointments for a patient, such as a yearly physical or a specialist referral appointment. The doctor's request will be added to the sick call sheet and the patient will be informed and escorted to the appointment.

Insurance:
Patients in the corrections system rarely need to worry about insurance as the cost of their healthcare while in the system is the responsibility of the Department of Corrections.

Billing:
In most cases, the patient is not required to pay for care. Some locales do require some kind of co-pay for services with the rationale of cutting down on abuse of the sick call system and healthcare/security costs, but the by-and-large corrections healthcare practice is to provide access to healthcare without requiring any money from patients.

title: Multiple Choice Question
body: A correctional facility must provide a sick call visit within how long after a patient submits a request?
instruction: Choose one option and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Correct. Correctional Facilities are open around-the-clock and often need to see patients at all hours of the day.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. Correctional Facilities are open around-the-clock and often need to see patients at all hours of the day.

title: One last question
body: A patient who is under the influence of drugs or alcohol will be accepted for intake at custody.
instruction: Choose an option and select Submit.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Correct - However, a patient will not be accepted at Nurse Intake unless they are sober.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect - As long as the patient is stable and conscious, they can pass through custody; nurse intake will not proceed until a patient is sober
